name: Swift
title: This cheat sheet provides examples of using Swift that cover basic Swift knowledge, control flow etc.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: This cheat sheet provides examples of using Swift that cover basic Swift knowledge, control flow etc.

cards.title: Variable
cards.code:
var score = 0  // Variable
let pi = 3.14  // Constant

var greeting = "Hello"
var numberOfToys = 8
var isMorning = true

var numberOfToys: Int = 8
numberOfToys += 1

print(numberOfToys)
// prints "9"

cards.title: Type annotations
cards.code:
var greeting: String = "Hello"
var numberOfToys: Int = 8
var isMorning: Bool = true
var price: Double = 8.99

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.body:
â€¢ `+` Add
â€¢ `-` Subtraction
â€¢ `*` Multiplication
â€¢ `/` Division
â€¢ `%` Remainder

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.code:
var x = 0
x = 4 + 2 // x is now 6
x = 4 - 2 // x is now 2
x = 4 * 2 // x is now 8
x = 4 / 2 // x is now 2
x = 4 % 2 // x is now 0

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.body:
â€¢ `+=` Adds and assigns sums
â€¢ `-=` subtract and assign the difference
â€¢ `*=` Multiplication and assignment
â€¢ `/=` Divide and assign quotient
â€¢ `%=` Divide and assign remainder

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.body: #### Compound Assignment Operators

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.code:
var numberOfDogs = 100
numberOfDogs += 1
print("There are \(numberOfDogs) Dalmatians!")

// print: There are 101 Dalmatians!

cards.code:

cards.code: // MARK: -view settings

cards.title: Special comment syntax (MARK)
cards.body: `MARK` can be used to display comments in the column

cards.title: Special comment syntax (TODO)

cards.body: `TODO` is used to display reminders of things that need to be done

cards.code: // FIXME: Fix buggy behavior when making changes to existing entries

cards.title: Special Comment Syntax (FIXME)
cards.body: `FIXME` is used to display reminders about things that need to be fixed

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.body: Variables are declared with `var`:

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.code:
var greeting = "Hello"
var numberOfToys = 8
var isMorning = true

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.body: For clarity, variable declarations can contain type annotations:

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.code:
var greeting: String = "Hello"
var numberOfToys: Int = 8
var isMorning: Bool = true

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.body: Variables are mutable. Their values be changed:

cards.title: Variable declaration
cards.code:
var numberOfToys: Int = 8
numberOfToys += 1

print(numberOfToys)
// print "9"

cards.title: Constants
cards.body: Constants are declared with `let`:

cards.title: Constants
cards.code:

let numberOfToys = 8
let isMorning = true

cards.title: Constants
cards.body: For clarity, constant declarations can contain type annotations:

cards.title: Constants
cards.code:
let greeting: String = "Hello"
let numberOfToys: Int = 8
let isMorning: Bool = true

cards.title: Constants
cards.body: Constants are immutable. Their values can not be changed:

cards.body:

keyword `get`:

willSet
cards.body: `willSet` can be used to execute some code before setting the variable value

willSet and didSet
if statement

Comparison Operators
cards.code:
5 > 1      // true
6 < 10     // true
2 >= 3     // false
3 <= 5     // true
"A" == "a" // false
"B" != "b" // true

cards.title: Comparison Operators
cards.body:
-`<` less than
-`>` greater than
-`<=` less than or equal to
-`>=` greater than or equal to
-`==` is equal to
-`!=` is not equal to

cards.title: Range Operators
cards.code:
a...b      // numbers between a and b (including both a and b)
a..<b      // numbers between a and b (including a but excluding b)
...b      // numbers till b (including b)

cards.title: Range Operators
cards.body:
-`a...b` Closed Range
-`a.. -`...b` One-Sided Range

cards.title: Ternary conditional operator
cards.code:
var driverLicense = true

driverLicense
    ? print("driver seat") : print("passenger seat")
// print: driver's seat

cards.title: switch statement
switch statement: interval matching
cards.code:
let year = 1905
var artPeriod: String

switch year {
  case 1860...1885:
    artPeriod = "Impressionism"
  case 1886...1910:
    artPeriod = "Post-Impressionism"
  default:
    artPeriod = "Unknown"
}
// print: post-impressionism

cards.title: switch statement: composite case
cards.code:
let service = "Seamless"

switch service {
case "Uber", "Lyft":
    print("travel")
  case "DoorDash", "Seamless", "GrubHub":
    print("Restaurant delivery")
  case "Instacart", "FreshDirect":
    print("Grocery Delivery")
  default:
    print("Unknown service")
}
// print: restaurant takeaway

cards.title: switch statement: where clause
Logical Operators
cards.code:
!true  // false
!false //true

cards.title: Logical Operators &&
cards.code:
true && true   // true
true && false  // false
false && true  // false
false && false // false

cards.title: Logical operators ||
cards.code:
true || true   // true
true || false  // true
false || true  // true
false || false // false

cards.title: Combined Logical Operators
cards.code: !false && true || false // true

cards.title: Combined Logical Operators
cards.body:
`!false && true` first evaluates and returns `true` Then, the expression, `true` || `false` evaluates and returns the
final result `true`

cards.title: Combined Logical Operators
cards.code: false || true && false // false

cards.title: Combined Logical Operators
cards.body:
`true && false` first evaluates to return `false` Then, the expression, `false` || `false` evaluates and returns the
final result `false`

cards.title: Control the order of execution
Simple guards
scope
cards.code:
let zeroToThree = 0...3
//zeroToThree: 0, 1, 2, 3

cards.title: stride() function
for-in loop
continue keyword
continue keyword
cards.body: The `continue` keyword will force the loop to continue for the next iteration

cards.title: break keyword
Use underscores
while loop
while loop
cards.body:
A `while` loop accepts a condition and keeps executing its body code while the provided condition is `true`. If the
condition is never false, the loop will keep running and the program will get stuck in an `infinite loop`

cards.title: Array
cards.code:
var scores = [Int]()
// array is empty: []

cards.title: .count property
index
cards.body:
The index refers to the item's position in the ordered list, and a single element is retrieved from the array using the
subscript syntax `array[index]`.

cards.title: index
cards.code:
var vowels = ["a", "e", "i", "o", "u"]

print(vowels[0]) // prints: a
print(vowels[1]) // prints: e
print(vowels[2]) // print: i
print(vowels[3]) // prints: o
print(vowels[4]) // prints: u

cards.title: index
cards.body: Note: Swift arrays are zero-indexed, meaning the first element has index 0.

cards.code:
var paintingsInMOMA: Set = [
  "The Dream",
  "The Starry Night",
  "The False Mirror"
]

cards.title: Collection (Set)
cards.body: We can use a collection (`Set`) to store `unique` elements of the same data type

cards.title: Empty collection (Set)
Populate the collection
cards.code: var vowels: Set = ["a", "e", "i", "o","u"]

cards.title: Populate the collection
cards.body: To create a set filled with values, use the `Set` keyword before the assignment operator.

cards.title: .insert()
.remove() and .removeAll() methods
.contains()
.isEmpty property
cards.code:
var emptyList = [String]()
print(emptyList.isEmpty)     // print: true

var populatedList: [Int] = [1, 2, 3]
print(populatedList.isEmpty) // print: false

cards.title: Iterate over a collection
.isEmpty property
cards.code:
var emptySet = Set<String>()
print(emptySet.isEmpty)     // print: true

var populatedSet: Set = [1, 2, 3]
print(populatedSet.isEmpty) // print: false

cards.title: .count property
.intersection() Intersection
cards.code:
var setA: Set = ["A", "B", "C", "D"]
var setB: Set = ["C", "D", "E", "F"]

var setC = setA.intersection(setB)
print(setC) // print: ["D", "C"]

cards.title: .union()
.symmetricDifference() Symmetric difference
.subtracting() Subtraction
Base Dictionary
cards.code:
var dictionaryName = [
  "Key1": "Value1",
  "Key2": "Value2",
  "Key3": "Value3"
]

cards.title: Base Dictionary
cards.body: An `unordered` collection of pairs of data or key-value pairs

cards.title: Keys
cards.code:

  "Coconuts": 12,
  "Pineapples": 12,
  "Papaya": 12

cards.title: Keys
cards.body: Each `key` is `unique` even if they all contain the same `value`

cards.title: Type Consistency
cards.body: Contains only `String` keys and `Int` values

cards.title: Initialize an empty dictionary
add to dictionary
Delete key-value pair
Modify the key-value pair
Modify the key-value pair
cards.body:
To change the value of a key-value pair, use the `.updateValue()` method or the subscript syntax by appending brackets
`[ ]` with the existing keys within to the name of the dictionary, then adding the assignment operator _(`= `)_ followed
by the modified value

cards.title: .isEmpty property
.count property
cards.code:
var fruitStand = [
  "Apples": 12,
  "Oranges", 17
]
print(fruitStand.count) // print: 2

Assigning values to variables
cards.body:
Assigning the value of a key-value pair to a variable will return an optional value. To extract values, use the optional
expansion

cards.code:
var currentSeason = "Winter"

func season(month: Int, name: inout String) {
  switch month {
    case 1...2:
      name = "Winter â›„ï¸"
    case 3...6:
      name = "Spring ðŸŒ±"
    case 7...9:
      name = "Summer â›±"
    case 10...11:
      name = "Autumn ðŸ‚"
    default:
      name = "Unknown"
  }
}
season(month: 4, name: &currentSeason)

print(currentSeason) // Spring ðŸŒ±

cards.title: variable parameter
Optional parameters
Optional parameters
cards.body:
Functions can accept optional types and return optional types. When a function cannot return a reasonable instance of
the requested type, it should return `nil`

cards.title: Structure Creation
Structure Creation
cards.body:
Structs or structs are used to programmatically represent real-life objects in code. A structure is created using the
`struct` keyword, followed by its name, followed by a body containing its properties and methods

cards.title: init() method
cards.body:
A class can be initialized using the `init()` method and the corresponding initialization properties. In the `init()`
method, the `self` keyword is used to refer to the actual instance of the class assigning property values

cards.title: Class Attributes
cards.code:

ferris.name = "Ferris Bueller"
ferris.year = 12
ferris.gpa = 3.81
ferris.honors = false

cards.title: Inherit
cards.body: Suppose we have a BankAccount class:

cards.title: Inherit
Inherit
cards.body: `SavingsAccount` extends `BankAccount` class

cards.title: Inherit
Inherit
cards.body:
The new `SavingsAccount` class (subclass) automatically gets all the characteristics of the `BankAccount` class
(superclass). Additionally, the `SavingsAccount` class defines an `.interest` property and an `.addInterest()` method.

cards.title: Define the enumeration
cards.code:
enum Day {
  case monday
  case tuesday
  case wednesday
  case thursday
  case friday
  case saturday
  case sunday
}

let casualWorkday: Day = .friday

cards.title: Switch statement
CaseIterable
CaseIterable
cards.body:
Add conformance to the `CaseIterable` protocol to access the `allCases` property, which returns an array of all cases of
the enumeration

cards.title: Original value
Related values
instance method
instance method
cards.body:
Just like classes and structs, enumerations can have instance methods. If an instance method mutates the value of the
enum, it needs to be marked `mutating`

cards.title: Initialize from primitive value
Computed properties
What are extensions?
cards.body:
Extensions is a way to add new add new functionality to existing classes, structures, enumerations, or protocol types.
This includes adding new methods, properties, initializers, and more.

cards.title: Why use extensions?
cards.body:
Extensions are particularly useful for organizing and modularizing our code without needing to modify the original type,
especially when we don't have access to the original source code.

cards.title: Extension syntax
Computed properties
Methods
Mutating methods
Initializers
Subscripts
Protocol extensions
cards.body:
It works pretty much like abstract classes when regarding a functionality we want to be available in all the classes
that implements some protocol (without having to inherit from a base common class).

cards.title: Protocol extensions
Constraints for extensions
cards.body:
This is especially useful when we want to add functionality to a type that conforms to a specific protocol or has
certain conditions.

cards.title: Constraints for extensions
Organizing code with extensions
cards.body:
Extensions are not limited to adding functionality; they are also handy for code organization. We can group related
methods, properties or views in separate extensions.

cards.title: Organizing code with extensions
What are generics?
cards.body:
Generics in Swift are a feature that allows us to create functions, classes, structures, and protocols that can work
with any data type.

cards.title: Why use generics?
cards.body:
Generics enable us to write clear and concise code that works with any data type. By using placeholders (like `T`), this
reduces the risk of introducing bugs.

cards.title: Type parameters
Type parameters
cards.body: The placeholders `T` is an example of a type parameter, are written inside angle brackets(such as `<T>`).

cards.title: Generic Data Structures
Generic Functions
cards.code:
func swapValues<T>(_ a: inout T, _ b: inout T) {
    let temp = a
    a = b
    b = temp
}

var a = 10
var b = 20
swapValues(&a, &b)
print(a) // Output: 20
print(b) // Output: 10

var c = "Hello"
var d = "World"
swapValues(&c, &d)
print(c) // Output: "World"
print(d) // Output: "Hello"

cards.title: Constraints on Generics
Associated Types
Associated Types
cards.body:
Associated types are used in protocols to define a placeholder for a type that will be specified later. They act as a
generic placeholder. The exact type isn't defined in the protocol itself; instead, it's determined when a class, struct,
or enum conforms to the protocol.

cards.title: Generic Protocols
Generic Typealiases
cards.body: Generic typealiases allow us to create a new name for an existing type (i.e., they would not introduce a new type).

cards.title: Generic Typealiases
cards.code:
typealias StringDictionary<T> = [String: T]
typealias IntFunction<T> = (Int) -> Int
typealias Vector<T> = (T, T, T)
